questions.one: How do you adopt a tree?
questions.two: How do you record tree care activities?
questions.four: Where can I find a list of the trees I've adopted?
questions.six: What should I do if my tree is severely damaged or it looks like there is insect/fungi damage?
questions.seven: What should I do if my tree is no longer there?
questions.eight: Should I put plants in the tree pit with the tree?

one: Click "Sign-Up" at the top right corner to create an account.
Once you're logged in, enter your address in the search bar on the map to find adoptable trees near you.
Click on the icon of the tree you'd like to adopt, either the blue triangle for a newly planted tree or a green circle for an older tree.
Click on the "Adopt" button on the next screen to adopt that tree. It will be added to the "My Trees" list so you can easily find your tree and record your tree care activities.

Record each activity by clicking on "My Trees", finding the tree you adopted, and submitting the tree care activity on that tree's page. It's easy, and it helps us track the success of the Adopt-A-Tree program!

two.one: Go to <homeLink>map.treeboston.org/home</homeLink> and click on "My Trees".
two: On the right-hand side of your screen, click "More Info" under the tree you cared for.
You should see this on your screen where you can enter what you did and when:

three: On your tree's page, click on the "unadopt" button that is in place of the original adopt button. Please make
sure to "unadopt" trees you are no longer able to care for so others have the opportunity to adopt them and
the trees can get the care they need.
answers.five: Yes! We encourage you to adopt as many trees as you'd like. We do ask that you "unadopt" trees you are no longer able to care for so others can adopt and care for those trees.
answers.six: You will need to submit a <boston311Link>311 request</boston311Link> to the city. If it is a hazard, you should use the word "hazard" in your 311 request and try to describe it specifically - a broken limb in the canopy that is dangling overhead, for instance, or an increased lean of the main trunk and visible signs of fungal disease. This information will help the City Arborists triage requests that relate to public safety.
answers.seven: If your tree has been removed, or there is an empty pit near you and you'd like a tree there, you should submit a <boston311Link>311 request</boston311Link> to the city.
answers.eight: Please do not plant anything within the tree pits. You may mulch the tree if you'd like and weed the pit.
